entry.title: Hey there, welcome!
entry.content:
My name is Theo and I am a Software Engineer specializing in Augmented Reality, Computer Vision and Graphics.

If you are interested in my work, you can read about my projects here, watch some demos here, or download the source code here. If you want to learn more about me and my journey keep reading!

I grew up in Athens, Greece. My mother is from New York and my father from Istiaia.

I received my Electrical & Computer Engineering degree (5yr) from the University of Patras, in 2016. During my time in UPatras, I researched the field of Augmented Reality under the supervision of the brilliant Konstantinos Moustakas. Together, we worked on a project called 'Augmented Reality 3D Maps' which led to a publication soon after graduation.

During the summers of 2015 and 2016 I interned as a Software Engineer with Mantis Informatics S.A., where I developed Heads Up Display (HUD) applications for warehouse environments. I worked with various devices (Vuzix M100, Moverio BT-200, etc) and attempted to reduce the time spent in the most expensive process of warehousing: Order Picking.

After graduation, I embarked on my 9 month mandatory military service in the Greek Army (NATO forces); first as a tank commander on the border and finally as an engineer in Athens HQ. Upon completion of my service (Aug. 2017), I moved to the US to pursue my MS CS degree in Georgia Tech, where I specialize in Computer Graphics & Vision.

During school time, I work with Dr. Thad Starner, inventor of Google Glass and HMD expert, as a Head Teaching Assistant for his Artificial Intelligence graduate course. As Head TA I lead a team of 15+ GTAs, managing 400+ online graduate students and 100+ on-campus. I am responsible for substitute teaching, course content, midterm and final exams etc.

Under his supervision, I also research the field of Head Mounted Displays and Wearables, working on various different projects and publications (latest paper on ISWIC '2018).

During the summer I interned with Amway as a Software Engineer, working on mobile Augmented Reality. I worked in the R&D department, developing interactive AR applications for Amway's own product lines. My app prototypes were received well and were ultimately incorporated into production.

Let's connect!

entry.title: Augmented Reality Intern
entry.content:
During the Summer of 2018 I interned with Amway's R&D, working on mobile Augmented Reality (AR) applications.

My job was to explore Augmented Reality as a technology and find possible use cases for Amway. To that end, I designed and developed 2 AR prototypes focused on interactive packaging.

My goal was to enhance the Amway experience by adding a digital extension to Amway packages. I worked on both the social/promotional aspect of Augmented Reality as well as the immersive/entertaining one.

The internship involved a final presentation, where I pitched my work and its importance to approximately 100 Amway employees (management, marketing, etc.). The presentation included live demos of the prototypes and an extensive Q&A session. The project was received very well.

Tools


I developed 2 iOS applications, using Obj-C (not Swift, because of library limitations).

The AR applications were built on the Vuforia AR library, and on a combination of OpenGL ES & Scenekit for 3D rendering. Additional tools like Blender were also utilized.

entry.title: Head Mounted Displays in Warehouses
entry.content:
For the best part of my time here in Georgia Tech I have worked with Dr. Thad Starner as a researcher in Head Mounted Displays. Thad is a great mentor; he's a Georgia Tech Professor, the director of the Contextual Computing Group and the Technical Lead on Google Glass.

Together with Thad, Charu Thomas, Pramod Kotipalli and Sarthak Srinivas we've been exploring the disruptive potential of Head Mounted Displays in the Warehousing industry.

Why Warehouses?

The rise of Head Mounted Displays will inevitably impact all industries that rely on human labor. More than 55% of the operational costs of a warehouse are spent in a process called 'Order Picking', where employees travel around the warehouse collecting items and fulfilling customer orders.

Due to the highly specialized nature of this task, it is a task still largely done manually. The industry standard right now involves pickers carrying paper lists or handheld barcode scanners, both solutions being far from ideal.

Head Mounted Displays have the potential to revolutionize Order Picking since they allow pickers to have both hands free for the actual picking task. They can provide navigation services, highlight the items on the racks for easier picking and much more.

My contribution to the field involves two projects; one focused on RFID wearables for verification and one tackling in-doors navigation.

Heads Up Displays with RFID verification

Heads Up Displays have already been proven to increase picking speed. They still, however, face a big challenge.

When pickers scan item locations with a barcode scanner, the Warehouse Management System (WMS) verifies that they're picking the correct item saving them from potential errors. Heads Up Displays lack such a verification system.

Our goal was to give an answer to this shortcoming by utilizing wearable RFID bands. The bands would recognize passive RFID tags located near bins, and would seamlessly verify a pick, returning positive or negative results straight to the HUD (Google Glass). We developed and tested our method against current industry standards (pick-by-paper, pick-to-light, pick-by-barcode).

We conducted a 12 person user study in a model warehouse and found our method to be faster, less prone to errors and less taxing to the users than all methods currently used in the industry.

The work was published in the International Symbosium on Wearable Computers, ISWC '18, in Singapore, with the title- "RF-Pick: Comparing Order Picking Using a HUD with Wearable RFID Verification to Traditional Pick Methods".

In-doors Navigation

Reducing picking time and errors only solves part of the problem. 50% of the time and thus the cost of Order Picking is spent in-between picks, when a picker is walking from one location to another.

Our goal was to reduce the travelling time by means of optimization and navigation. Warehouses are complicated structures and can become very crowded and very hectic. A navigation system, like an in-doors Maps application, can help pickers traverse the Warehouse more quickly and more efficiently.

Our goal was not to design an in-doors Real Time Location System (RTLS) since such systems already exist. Instead, we focused on the client application that would run on a Heads Up Display. Ultimately we wanted to investigate whether such a Navigation system could reduce travelling time and by what amount.

We tested our method in Georgia Tech's library. We gave subjects a list of books either in a paper form or directly to the HUD, and they would have to pick them and fulfill the order. Our goal was to determine whether HUD with Navigation could actually reduce the time wasted in between picks.

This study is still on-going.

entry.title: Lattice Mesh Generation
entry.content:
The goal of this project was to generate a custom 3D lattice support structure in between two arbitrary surfaces. These single-mesh lattice structures have a variety of uses in the medical field. They can be 3D printed and inserted into the human body to support a vain or a damaged organ.

Here's the process we followed given two arbitrary planar point clouds:

  • We first triangulate (Delaunay) the two point clouds and generate two parallel planar surfaces.
  • We then implement Delaunay Tetrahedralization to fill the space in between the two planes with tetrahedra primitives.
  • We use the edges of the tetrahedra as support beams for our lattice.
  • Finally, we use the ball-pivoting algorithm to generate a single 3D mesh from all the primitives. This step is crucial since it allows 3D printing.

Project completed by me and Sandeep Bangalore at Georgia Tech, Atlanta.

entry.title: Hackathon 1st place
entry.content:
Our Card-Cache application won the 1st prize in the Career App challenge in the Hack GT 2017 Hackathon.

Card-Cache is a mobile app which can detect business cards, parse them, translate them and save them in your e-wallet!

Our team consisted of 4 people. My responsibilities were to handle the Computer Vision aspects of the app (detection, parsing and translation).

entry.title: University of Patras
entry.content:
I graduated from the University of Patras in 2016, with a B.E. in Electrical & Computer Engineering.

An Engineering Degree in Greece is a 5 year program with a 2 year specialization. My specialization was in Electronics & Computers and my Thesis was in Augmented Reality.

During my 4th and 5th year, I worked in the VVR lab under the supervision of Konstantinos Moustakas working in Computer Vision and Computer Graphics projects. You can find samples of my work here and here.

I graduated in the top 12% of my class with a 7.82/10 grade. I was also in the 3% that managed to finish the degree in the 5 year time-frame.
